2. In the spring We-beorn took in settlement land between Scate-frith and Horse-frith, as far as a man could walk in a day, and that piece over which is called Foal-fort.

We-beorn was a great fighting man, and there is a great history of him. He gave his sister We-dis in wedlock to Grim-wolf of Unad’s-dale. They fell into quarrel, and We-beorn slew him hard by Grim-wolf’s-mere, wherefore We-beorn was slain at Theng-eyre-moot in Deer-frith, and three men beside. [112]

26. 1. Gunnsteinn ok Halldórr héto syner Gunnbiarnar, es Gunnbiarnar-sker ’ro við kend. Gunnbiꜵrn vas son Ulfs Krꜵ́ko. Þeir nꜵ́mo Skoto-fiꜵrð, ok Laugar-dal, ok Ogurs-vík ▼ til Mióva-fiarðar. Berse vas son Halldórs, faðer Þórmóðar Colbrúnar-skallz. Þar í Laugar-dale bió síðan Þórbiꜵrn Þióðreks5 son, es vá Óláf, son Hávarðar Halta ok Biargeyjar Valbranz-dóttor.—Þar af gœrðesk Saga Ísfirðinga, ok víg Þórbiarnar.

26. 1. Gund-stan and Hall-dor were the names of the sons of that Gund-beorn after whom Gund-beorn’s-reef is called. Gund-beorn was the son of Wolf-crow. They took in settlement Scate-frith, and Bath-dale, and Wash-wick up to Slim-frith. Berse was the son of Hall-dor, and the father of Thor-mod, Coal-brow’s poet. There in Bath-dale dwelt afterwards Thor-beorn, Theod-rec’s son, who slew An-laf, the son of Haward the Halt and of Bearg-ey, Wal-brand’s daughter, whereof is made the History of the Ice-frith-folk and the Slaughter of Thor-beorn.

2. Snæbiꜵrn, son Eyvindar Austmannz, bróðer Helga Magra, nam land miðle Mióva-fiarðar ok Langa-dals-ár, ok bió í Vatz-firðe. Hans son vas Holmsteinn, faðer Snæbiarnar Gallta, es vá10 Hallbiꜵrn, son Oddz at Kiðja-berge, hiá Hallbiarnar-vꜵrðom. Hann hafðe áðr veget Hallgerðe kono sína, dóttor Tungo-Oddz. Móðer Snæbiarnar Galltar vas Ceolvor, ok vóro þeir Tungo-Oddr systra-syner. Snæbiꜵrn vas fóstraðr í Þingnese með Þórodde, en stundom vas hann með Tungo-Odde eða móðor sínne.15

2. Snow-beorn, the son of Ey-wind the East-man, the brother of Helge the Lean, took land in settlement between Slim-frith and Lang-dale-water, and dwelt at Water-frith. His son was Holm-stan, the father of Snow-beorn-Galte [boar], who slew Hall-beorn, Ord’s son, at Kid-rock, hard by Hall-beorn’s-ward or Hall-beorn’s-cairn. He had before slain Hall-gerd, his wife, the daughter of Ord o’ Tongue.

[According to Hawk’s directions now followeth.]

The mother of Snow-beorn Boar was Ceol-ware, and they were first cousins [on the sister side] of Ord o’ Tongue. Snow-beorn was fostered at Thing-ness with Thor-ord; but sometimes he would be with Ord o’ Tongue or his mother.

3. Hallbiꜵrn, son Oddz frá Kiðja-berge, Hallkels sonar, bróðor Ketilbiarnar ens Gamla, feck Hallgerðar, dóttor Tungo-Oddz. Þau vóro með Odde enn fyrsta vetr. Þá vas Snæbiꜵrn Gallte þar. Óástugt vas með þeim hiónom. Hallbiꜵrn bió ferð sína um váret at Far-dꜵgom. En es hann vas í búnaðe, fór Oddr frá húse til20 laugar í Reykja-holt.—Þar vóro sauða-hús hans—ok vilde hann [113][151: ii. 30.]eige vesa við es Hallbiꜵrn fœ́re; þvi at hann grunaðe, at Hallgerðr mœnde eige fara vilja með hónom. Oddr hafðe iamnan um bœ́tt með þeim. Þá es Hallbiꜵrn hafðe lagt á hesta þeirra, geck hann í dyngjo; ok sat Hallgerðr á palle, ok kembðe ser; háret fell um hána alla ok á golfet.—Hon hefer kvenna bazt hærð vereð á5 Íslande með Hallgerðe Lang-brók ▼. Hallbiꜵrn bað hána upp standa ok fara; hón sat ok þagðe. Þá tók hann til hennar, ok lyptisk hon ecke ▼. Þrimr sinnom fór svá. Hallbiꜵrn nam stað fyrer henne ok kvað:

Olkarma lætr arman, eik, etc.10

3. Hall-beorn, the son of Ord of Kid-rock, the son of Hall-kel, the brother of Cetil-beorn the Old, took to wife Hall-gerd, Ord o’ Tongue’s daughter. They stayed with Ord the first winter [after their marriage], and Snow-beorn Boar was there at the time.

There was little love between the husband and wife. Hall-beorn made ready to depart by the flitting-days in the spring. But while he was getting ready to go, Ord went from his house to bathe at Reek-holt, [113]where his sheep-house was, for he did not wish to be at home when Hall-beorn went away, for he suspected that Hall-gerd would not be willing to go away with him. Ord had ever been a peace-maker between them. When Hall-beorn had saddled the horses, he went into the parlour or bower, and there sat Hall-gerd on the daïs combing her hair. The hair fell all over her and down on the floor, for she had the best hair of any woman that have ever been in Iceland (save Hall-gerd Long-breeks). Hall-beorn bade her stand up and come. She sat still and held her peace. Then he took hold of her, but she would not stir; and this happened three times. Then Hall-beorn stood up in front of her, and said [this verse]:—

The linen-veiled lady lets me stand as a beggar, etc.

[See Corpus Poet. Bor. ii. 79.]

Hann snaraðe háret of hꜵnd ser, ok vill kippa henne af pallenom; en hón sat ok veiksk eige efter. Þá brá hann sverðe, ok hió af henne hꜵfoðet. Síðan geck hann út, ok reið braut. Þeir vóro fiórer ▼ saman, ok hꜵfðo tvau klyfja-hross. Fátt vas manna heima. Þegar vas sent at segja Odde. Oddr seger: ‘Segið ér Snæbirne á Ceol-varar-stꜵðom;15 en ecke mon ek efter þeim ríða.’ Snæbiꜵrn reið efter þeim með tolfta mann. En es þeir Hallbiꜵrn siá efter-reið, bꜵ́ðo fꜵro-nautar Hallbiarnar hann undan ríða; en hann vilde þat eige. Þeir Snæbiꜵrn kómo efter þeim við hæðer þær, es nú heita Hallbiarnar-vꜵrðor. Þeir Hallbiꜵrn fóro á hæðena ok vꜵrðosk20 þaðan. Þar fello þrír ▼ menn af Snæbirne, en báðer fꜵro-nautar Hallbiarnar. Snæbiꜵrn hió þá fót af Hallbirne í ristar-lið; þá [114][153: ii. 30.]hnekðe hann á ena syðre hæð, ok vá þar enn tvá menn áðr hann fell—því ero þriár vꜵrðor á þeirre hæð, en fimm á hinne. Síðan fór Snæbiꜵrn aptr. ▼

He twisted her hair round his hand, and tried to drag her off the daïs, but she sat still, and never budged a whit the more. Then he drew his sword, and hewed off her head. Then he walked out and rode away. There were three men with him, and they had two pack-horses. There were few folk at home, and news was sent at once to Ord. Says Ord, ‘Go tell Snow-beorn at Ceol-ware-stead, for I will not ride after them.’ Snow-beorn rode after them with twelve men; but when Hall-beorn’s men saw men riding after them, they prayed Hall-beorn to ride off, but he would not. Snow-beorn and his men came up with them at the hillocks that are now called Hall-beorn’s-cairns. Hall-beorn and his [114]men went up on the hillocks, and defended themselves therefrom. There fell four [three] men of Snow-beorn’s, and both Hall-beorn’s companions. Then Snow-beorn hewed the foot off Hall-beorn at the ankle; then he hobbled into the southernmost hillock, and there he slew two more men ere he fell. There are three cairns on the hill there, but five on the other. Upon which Snow-beorn went back.

[Here something is missing. Snow-beorn was no doubt sought to be outlawed by the kinsmen of Hall-beorn, hence he determines to go abroad.]

4. ...Snæbiꜵrn átte skip í Grímsár-óse; ok keypte halft, Hrólfr enn Rauðsenzke: þeir vóro tolf hvárir. Með Snæbirne vóro5 þeir Þorkell (ok) Sumarliðe syner Þórgeirs Rauðs, Einars sonar Stafhyltings. Snæbiꜵrn tók við Þórodde or Þingnese, fóstra sínom, ok kono hans; en Hrólfr tók við Styrbirne, es þetta kvað efter draum sínn:

Bana sé-ek ockarn, beggja tveggja,10

Allt amorlegt út-norðr í haf:

Frost ok kulða, feikn hvers-konar,

Siꜵ́mk af svikom ▼ Snæbiꜵrn vegenn.

4. Snow-beorn had a ship in Grim’s-river-oyce, and Hrod-wolf of Red-sand bought half of her. There were twelve men with each of them. With Snow-beorn were Thor-kell and Summer-lid, the sons of Thor-gar the Red, the son of Einar the Staf-holting. Snow-beorn took with him Thor-ord of Thing-ness, his foster-son, and his wife; and Hrod-wolf took Styr-beorn, who made this verse after his dream:—

The bane I see of both of us

(It is dreary all) north-west in the main:

Frost and cold, horrors of all kinds:

I see Snow-beorn slain by treason.

[See Corpus Poet. Bor. ii. 361, No. 20.]

Þeir fóro at leita Gunnbiarnar-skerja, ok fundo land. Eige vilde Snæbiꜵrn kanna láta um nóttena. Styrbiꜵrn fór af skipe, ok fann15 fé-sióð í kumble, ok leynðe. Snæbiꜵrn laust hann með œxe; þá fell sióðrenn niðr. Þeir gœrðo skála, ok lagðe hann í fꜵnn. Þorkell Rauðs son fann at vatn vas á forke es út stóð í skála-gluggenn. Þat vas um Gœ ▼. Þá grófo þeir sik út. Snæbiꜵrn gœrðe [115][154: ii. 31.]at skipe; en þau Þóroddr vóro at skála af hans hende; en þeir Styrbiꜵrn af hende Hrólfs ▼; en aðrer fóro at veiðom. Styrbiꜵrn vá Þórodd; en þeir Hrólfr báðer Snæbiꜵrn. Rauðs-syner ok aller aðrer sóro eiða til lífs sér.

They went forth to seek Gund-beorn’s-reef, and discovered the land. Snow-beorn would not explore the land in the night. Styr-beorn went ashore, and found a bag of money in a cairn, and hid it. Snow-beorn struck him senseless with an ax, and the bag fell down. They made a hall, and it was all covered with snow. Thor-kell, the son of Red, found water on a fork, which was pushed out at the hall-luffer; that was in Goe [c. Feb. 10–March 10]. Then they dug themselves out. [115]Snow-beorn repaired the ship; but Thor-ord and his wife were at the hall on his behalf; and Styr-beorn and his men on behalf of Hrod-wolf; and the others were out hunting and fishing. Styr-beorn slew Thor-ord; and Hrod-wolf and he together slew Snow-beorn. Red’s sons and all the others swore oaths to them to save their own lives.

Þeir tóko Háloga-land, ok fóro þaðan til Íslannz, ok kómo í5 Vaðel. Þorkell Trefill gat sem faret hafðe fyrer Rauðs-sonom. Hrólfr gœrðe virke á Strandar-heiðe. Þorkell Trefill sende Sveinung til hꜵfuðs Hrólfe: fór hann fyrst á Mýre til Her­mundar; þá til Óláfs at Drꜵngom; þá til Gestz í Haga; hann sende hann til Hrólfs vinar síns. Sveinungr vá Hrólf ok Styr­biꜵrn:10 þá fór hann í Haga. Gestr skifte við hann sverðe ok œxe, ok feck hónom hesta tvá, hnockótta ▼, ok lét mann ríða um Vaðel, ok allt í Kolla-fiꜵrð: hann sende Þorbiꜵrn enn Sterka at heimta hestana; Þórbiꜵrn ▼ vá hann á Sveinungs-eyre, því at sverðet Sveinungs brotnaðe under hiꜵltonom. Því hœ́ldesk Trefill við Gest, þá15 es saman vas iamnat vite þeirra, at hann hefðe því komet á Gest, at hann sende sialfr mann til hꜵfuðs vin sínom.

They made Heleygo-land, and thence came to Iceland, and put in at Waddle. Thor-kell Trefil guessed what had happened to the sons of Red. Hrod-wolf built a work or fort on Strand-heath. Thor-kell Trefil sent Swegenung to take the head of Hrod-wolf [to slay him]. He went first to Her-mund at Mire; then to Anlaf at the Drongs; then to Guest at Hayes. He sent him to his friend Hrod-wolf. Swegenung slew Hrod-wolf and Styr-beorn; then he went to Hayes.

Guest exchanged sword and ax with him, and lent him two horses, white and black-maned, and sent a man to ride over Waddle as far as Coll’s-frith, to tell Thor-beorn the Strong to fetch back the horses. He slew Swegenung at Swegenung’s-eyre, because Swegenung’s sword broke off at the hilt. Trefil used to boast against Guest wherever their wits were compared together, that he had out-witted Guest when he made him send a man for the head of his own friend.

5. Óláfr Iamna-collr nam land frá Langa-dals-ꜵ́ til Sandeyrar-ár, ok bió í Unaðs-dale; hann átte Þóríðe ▼ Gunnsteins dóttor: þeirra son Grímolfr, es átte Védíse, systor Vébiarnar ▼.20

5. Anlaf Even-Coll took land in settlement from Lang-dale-water to Sand-eyre-water, and dwelt at Unad’s-dale. He had to wife Thor-rid [S: Thora], Gund-stan’s daughter. Their son was Grim-wolf, who had We-dis to wife, the sister of We-beorn.

6. Þórolfr ▼ Fasthalde hét maðr ágætr í Sogne. Hann varð úsáttr [116][156: ii. 31]við Hákon iarl Griótgarðz son, ok fór hann til Íslannz ▼; ok nam hann land frá Sandeyrar-ꜵ́ til Gygjar-spors-ár í Hrafns-firðe, ok bió at Snæfiꜵllom. Hans son vas Ufeigr, faðer ▼ Otkotlo.

6. Thor-wolf Fast-holder was the name of a nobleman in Sogn. [116]He was at odds with earl Hacon, Grit-gard’s son, and came to Iceland [al. by the counsel of king Harold], and took land in settlement there from Sand-eyre-water to Giantess-step-water in Raven’s-frith, and dwelt at Snow-fells. His son was Un-fey, the father of [al. who had to wife] Ot-katla.

27. 1. Œrlygr, son Bꜵðvars Vígsterks (sonar); hann fór til Íslannz fyr ofríke Harallz konungs Hárfagra, ok5 vas enn fyrsta vetr með Geirmunde Heljar-skinn. En um váret gaf Geirmundr hónom bústað í Aðal-vík, ok lꜵnd þau sem þar lꜵ́go til. Œrlygr átte Signýjo, dóttor Óblauðs, systor ▼ Hꜵgna ens Hvíta: þeirra son vas Cetill Gufa es átte Yre Geirmundar dóttor. Œrlygr eignaðesk Slétto ok Iokul-fiorðo.10

27. 1. Aur-lyg [was] the son of Bead-were Wig-stark’s son [O’ S ...?]. He came to Iceland by reason of the oppression of king Harold Fairhair, and stayed the first winter with Gar-mund Hell-skin. But in the spring Gar-mund gave him a place for a homestead in Ethel-wick, and the lands that appertained thereto. Aur-lyg had to wife Sig-ny, daughter of Un-blate, sister of Hagene the White. Their son was Cetil Gufa [Cathal Gobha], who had to wife Yra, Gar-mund’s daughter. Aur-lyg owned Sletta and Iockle-friths.

2. Nú taka til land-nꜵ́m Geirmundar ▼ [es nú ero almenningar], sem fyrr es ritað, allt til Straum-ness fyr austan Horn.

2. And now beginneth the tale of that Settlement of Gar-mund [which was turned into commons], as was written before, as far as Stream-ness from the east of Horn.

28. 1. Hella-biorn, son Herfinnz ok Hꜵllo, vas víkingr mikill: hann vas iamnan úvin Harallz konungs. Hann kom til Íslannz í Biarnar-fiꜵrð með alskiꜵldoðo skipe—síðan15 vas hann Skialda-Biꜵrn kallaðr. Hann nam land frá Straum-nese til Dranga: hann bió í Skialda-Biarnar-vík; en átte annat bú í Biarnar-nese—þar sér miklar skála-tofter hans.—Son hans vas Þórbiꜵrn, faðer Arngerðar, es átte Þióðrekr Sleito-Biarnar son. Þeirra syner Þórbiꜵrn, ok Sturla, ok Þióðrekr.20 [117] [157: ii. 32.]

28. 1. Slate-beorn, the son of Her-fin and Halla, was a great wicking. He was ever a foe of king Harold. He came to Iceland, and put into Beorn’s-frith with his ship, all set with shields; and ever after he was called Beorn o’ the Shields. He took land in settlement from Stream-ness to Drong. He dwelt at Shield-Beorn-wick, and had another homestead in Beorn’s-ness, where are to be seen the great foundation-marks of his hall. His son was Thor-beorn, the father of Arn-gerd, whom Theod-rec, Sleight-Beorn’s son, had to wife. Their sons were Thor-beorn, and Sturla, and Theod-rec. [117]

2. Geirolfr hét maðr, es braut skip sítt við Geirolfs-gnúp: hann bió síðan under gnúpenom at ráðe Biarnar.

2. Gar-wolf was the name of a man that wrecked his ship on Gar-wolf’s-peak, and afterwards dwelt beneath this peak by the rede or counsel of Beorn.

3.  ▼Þórvaldr Ásvallz son, Ulfs son, Yxna-Þóris sonar nam Dranga-land ok Dranga-vík til Engi-ness, ok bió at Drꜵngom alla æve. Hans son vas Eirikr Rauðe, es bygðe Grœna-land, sem fyrr5 seger.

3. Thor-wald, the son of Os-wald [blank], the son of Wolf, the son of Oxen-Thoro, took in settlement Drong-land and Drong-wick up to Eng-ness [Meadow-ness or Hanger-ness], and dwelt at Drongs all his life. His son was Eiric the Red, who settled Greenland, as is said before.

4. Herrœðr Hvika-timbr ▼ vas gꜵfogr maðr; hann vas drepenn at rꜵ́ðom Harallz konungs. En syner hans þrír fóro til Íslannz, ok nꜵ́mo land á Strꜵndom: Eyvindr Eyvindar-fiꜵrð. Ófeigr Ófeigs-fiꜵrð, en Ingolfr Ingolfs-fiꜵrð. Þar bioggo þeir síðan.10

4. Here-rod Hwic-timber [al. White-sky] was a man of birth. He was slain by the contrivance of king Harold; and his three sons came to Iceland, and took land in settlement in the Strands—Ey-wind Ey-wind’s-frith, Un-fey Un-fey’s-frith, and Ing-wolf Ing-wolf’s-frith, and there they dwelt afterwards.

5. Eirikr Snara hét maðr, es land nam frá Ingolfs-firðe til Veiðe-lauso, ok Trékyllis-vík. Hann átte Álofo dóttor Ingolfs or Ingolfs-firðe. Þeirra son vas Flose, es bió í Vík þá es Austmenn bruto þar skip sítt; ok gœrðo or hrænom ▼ skip þat es þeir kꜵlloðo Tré-kylli. Á því fór Flose útan, ok varð aftr-reka í Œxar-fiꜵrð—þaðan15 af gœrðesk Saga Bꜵðmóðs Gerpis ▼ ok Grímolfs.

5. Eiric-snare was the name of a man that took land in settlement from Ing-wolf’s-frith to Fish-lease and Bag o’ Wood. He had to wife O-lof, the daughter of Ing-wolf of Ing-wolf’s-frith. Their son was Flose, that dwelt at Wick, where the Eastmen wrecked their ship, and built another ship out of the wreck, which was called Tree-bag or Bag o’ Wood, on board of which Flose set out to go abroad, but was driven back into Ax-frith, whereby arose the History of Bead-mod Gerpe and Grim-wolf.

29. 1. Onundr Tréfótr, son Ufeigs Burlu-fótar, Ívars sonar Beytils: Onundr vas á móti Harallde konunge í Hafrs-firðe, ok lét þar fót sínn. Efter þat fór hann til Íslannz, ok nam land frá Kleifom til Úfœ́ro, Kallbaks-vík, Kolbeins-vík,20 [118][158: ii. 32.]Byrgis-vík; ok bió í Kallbak til elle. Hann vas bróðer Goðbiargar, móðor Goðbrannz Kúlo, fꜵðor Ásto, móðor Óláfs konungs ens Helga. Onundr átte feóra sono; einn vas Grettir: annarr Þorgeirr Flosco-bak: þriðe Asgeirr Æðe-kollr, faðer Kalfs, ok Hrefno es Ceartan átte; ok Þóríðar, es Þorkell Cugge átte, en síðarr5 Steinþórr Óláfs son ▼ Pá: enn fiórðe son Onundar vas Þórgrímr Hæro-kollr, faðer Ásmundar, fꜵðor Grettiss ens Sterka.

29. 1. Ean-wend Tree-foot, the son of Un-fey Barb-foot, the son of Ing-were Beitel [Mare’s tail, Equisetum]. Ean-wend was against king Harold at Hafr’s-frith, and lost his foot there. After that he came to Iceland, and took in settlement land from Cliff to Un-fare, Cold-back-wick, Colban’s-wick, Burge’s-wick, and dwelt at Cold-back till his old age. He was the [118]brother of God-borg, the mother of God-brand Cula, the father of Asta, the mother of king Anlaf the Saint. Ean-wend had four sons: one was Grette; another Thor-gar Flask-back; a third Asgar Eider-duck, the father of Calf and of Raven, whom Ceartan had to wife, and of Thor-rid, whom Thor-kel Cug had to wife [first], but afterwards Stan-thor, the son of Anlaf Peacock, had her to wife; and the fourth son of Ean-wend was Thor-grim Hoar-pate, the father of Os-mund, the father of Grette the Strong.

2. Biꜵrn hét maðr, es nam Biarnar-fiꜵrð; hann átte Liúfo. Þeirra son vas Svanr at ▼ Svans-hóle, es þar bió síðan ok drucknaðe á firðenom, ok geck þar inn í fiallet at sýn.10

2. Beorn was the name of a man that took in settlement Beorn-frith. He had to wife Leva. Their son was Swan of Swan’s-hill, and dwelt there afterwards, and was drowned in the frith, and was seen to go into the fell, i.e. Swan’s-hill.

3. Steingrímr Trolle ▼ nam Steingríms-fiꜵrð allan, ok bió í Trolla-tungo. Hans son vas Þórer, faðer Halldórs, fꜵðor Þorvallz Orgoða, fꜵðor Bitro-Odda, fꜵðor Oddz [f. Há-Snorra, f. Oddz munks, ok Þorláks ok Þorarens Rosta]. ▼

3. Stan-grim Troll took in settlement Stan-grim’s-frith, and dwelt at Troll-tongue. His son was Thore, the father of Hall-dor, the father of Thor-wald Or-gode, the father of Ord of Bitter, the father of Stan-thor, the father of Ord, the father of High-Snorre, the father of Ord the monk, and of Thor-lac [S: Thor-hrolf] and Thor-arin Rosti [Tosti].

4. Colle hét maðr, es nam Colla-fiꜵrð, ok Skriðins-enne; ok15 bió under Felle meðan hann lifðe.

4. Coll was the name of a man that took in settlement Coll’s-frith and Scridin’s-brow, and dwelt under the Fell as long as he lived.

5. Þórbiꜵrn Bitra hét maðr; ok vas mikill víkingr ok ill-menne; hann fór til Íslannz með skullda-lið sítt. Hann nam fiꜵrð þann es nú heiter Bitra, ok bió þar. Nockoro síðarr braut Goðlaugr, bróðer Gils ▼ Skeiðar-nefs, skip sítt þar út við hꜵfða þann es nú20 heiter Goðlaugs-hꜵfðe. Goðlaugr komsk ▼ á land, ok kona hans [119][159: ii. 33.]ok dótter; en aðrer menn aller týndosk. Þá kom til Þórbiꜵrn Bitra ok myrðe þau bæðe; en tók meyna ok fœ́dde upp. En es þessa varð varr Gils Skeiðar-nef, fór hann til ok hefnde bróðor síns, ok drap Þórbiꜵrn Bitro, ok enn fleire menn aðra.—Við Goðlaug es kend Goðlaugs-vík.5

5. Thor-beorn Bitter was the name of a man that was a great wicking, and a wicked man. He came to Iceland with his household, and took in settlement the frith that is now called Bitter, and dwelt there. Somewhat later Gud-laug, the brother of Gils Galley-neb, wrecked his ship there on the west over against the headland that is now called Gud-laug’s-head. Gud-laug got ashore with his wife and [119]daughter, but all the other folk aboard were lost. There Thor-beorn Bitter found them, and he murdered them both, and took the child and brought her up. But when Gils Galley-neb was aware of this, he went forth thither and avenged his brother, and slew Thor-beorn Bitter and other men beside. Gud-laug’s-wick is called after Gud-laug.

30. 1. Balke hét maðr, son Blœings, Sóta sonar. Hann fór til Íslannz fyr ofríke Harallz konungs ▼, ok nam Hrúta-fiꜵrð allan, ok bió á Balka-stꜵðom hvꜵ́rom-tveggjom; ok síðarst í Bœ́, ok dó þar. Hans son vas Berse Goðlauss, es fyrst bió á Bersa-stꜵðom í Hrúta-firðe; en síðan nam hann Langa-vatz-dal,10 sem fyrr es ritið ▼, ok átte þar annat bú, áðr hann feck Þórdísar dóttor Þórhaddz or Hitár-dale, ok tók með Holms-land. Þeirra son vas Arngeirr, faðer Biarnar Hitdœ́la-kappa. Geirbiꜵrg vas dótter Balka, móðer Véleifs ens Gamla.

30. 1. Balce is the name of a man, the son of Clong, the son of Sote of Sote’s-ness. He was against king Harold at Hafr’s-frith, and after that he came to Iceland, and took in settlement all Ram-frith, and dwelt at both Balce-steads, and afterwards at By, and there he died. His son was Bearse God-leas [Temple-tenant?], who first dwelt at Berse-stead in Ram-frith, but afterwards he took in settlement Lang-mere-dale (as above is written); and they had another homestead before he took to wife Thor-dis, the daughter of Thor-hard of Hot-dale, and got Holm’s-land as her portion. Their son was Arn-gar, the father of Beorn the Hot-dale champion. Gar-borg was the daughter of Balce, the mother of We-laf the Old.

2. Arndís en Auðga, dótter Steinolfs ens Lága, nam síðan land15 í Hrúta-firðe, út frá Borð-eyre. Hon bió í Bœ́: hennar son vas Þórðr es bió fyrr í Múla í Saur-bœ́.

2. Arn-dis the Wealthy, daughter of Stan-wolf the Low, afterwards took land in settlement in Ram-frith out from Bord-eyre. She dwelt at By. Her son was Thord, that dwelt before at Mull in Sower-by.

3. Greniaðr ▼ ok Þrostr, syner Hermunder Holkins, nꜵ́mo land í Hrúta-firðe, inn frá Borð-eyre, ok bioggo at Melom. [Frá Gren-jaðe vas komenn Hesta-Geller prestr, en Ormr frá Þreste.] ▼ Sonr20 Þrastar vas Þórkell á Cers-eyre, faðer Goðrúnar, es átte Þórbiꜵrn [120][161: ii. 33.]Þynna, son Hrómundar Hallta. Þeir bioggo at Fagra-brecko. Þórleifr Hrómundar-fóstre vas son þeirra. Hásteinn hét enn ▼ son Hrómundar, þeir vóro aller um eitt ráð. Þórer hét son Þórkels ▼ Þrastar sonar: hann bió at Melom: Helga hét dótter hans.

3. Greniad and Throst, the sons of Her-mund Holcin, took land in settlement in Ram-frith inward from Bord-eyre, and dwelt at Mells. From Greniad was come Horse-Gelle the priest, but from Throst came Orm. The son of Throst was Thor-kell of Cears-eyre, the father of [120]God-run, whom Thor-beorn Thynna [ax], the son of Hrod-mund the Halt, had to wife. They dwelt at Fair-brink. Thor-laf Hrod-mund’s foster-son was their son.

Heah-stan was the name of another son of Hrod-mund. They were all of one mind. Thore was the name of a son of Thor-kell, Throst’s son. He dwelt at Mells. Helga was the name of his daughter.

4. Í þenna tíma kom Sleito-Helge út á Borð-eyre, ok Iorundr5 bróðer hans. Þeir vóro víkingar; þeir fóro aller til Mela; tolf vóro þeir, útan sveinar. Þá feck Helge Helgo Þóris dóttor. Þeim Hrómunde hurfo stóð-hross: þat kendo þeir þeim Helga, ok stemnde Miðfiarðar-Skegge þeim um stulð til Alþingiss; en þeir Hrómundr skyldr gæta héraðs, ok hꜵfðo virke gótt á Brecko.10 Austmenn bioggo skip sítt.

4. At that time Sleight Helge came out to Bord-eyre, and Eor-wend his brother. They were wickings. They all went to Mells; they were twelve together without their servants. At that time Helge took to wife Helga, Thore’s daughter. Hrod-mund and his fellows lost a stud of horses, and charged Helge and his fellows with it, and Mid-frith Sceg summoned them to the All-Moot for theft; but Hrod-mund was to watch over the district, and make a strong work or fort at Brink. The Eastmen got ready their ship.

Þat vas einn morgin at hrafn kom á lióra á Brecko, ok gall hátt. Þá kvað Hrómundr:

Út heyr-ek svan sveita....

One morning it came to pass that a raven came on the luffer at Brink and croaked shrilly. Then quoth Hrod-mund:—

Outside I hear the raven in the morning:

So in times of yore when kings were doomed they screamed.

[See Corpus Poet. Bor. ii. 56, 57.]

Þórbiꜵrn kvað:15

Hlackar hagle....

Thor-beorn quoth—[repetition of same sentences in different words].

Í þenna tíma kómo Austmenn í virket; þvi at verkmenn hꜵfðo eige aftr láteð. Þeir brœ́ðr gengo út. Konor sꜵgðo Hrómund of gamlan, en Þórleif of ungan at ganga út—hann vas xix ▼ vetra. Hann hlióp út ok Þórleifr með vꜵ́pnom sínom ok kvað:20 [121] [163: ii. 33.]

Vara mer í dag dauðe ...

At that very time the Eastmen got into the work; for the workmen had not shut the work after them. The brothers went forth [to fight]. The women said that Hrod-mund was too old, and Thor-laf too young to go forth [to fight]. Thor-laf was then 19 [15] winters old. He and Hrod-mund ran out with their weapons, and Hrod-mund quoth:— [121]

My death day was not marked out for me to-day or yesterday.

I care not though swords play on red shields.—[See Corpus Poet. Bor. ii. 57.]

Austmenn fello sex í virkeno, en aðrer sex ▼ stucko í braut. En þá es Þórbiꜵrn vilde loka aftr virket, skaut Iorundr atgeir í gegnom hann. Þórbiꜵrn tók atgeir ór sáreno, ok sette miðle herða Iorunde, sva at út kom um briósteð; ok fello þeir báðer dauðer5 á iꜵrð. Helge greip upp Iꜵrund, ok kastaðe hónom á bak ser, ok rann svá. Hásteinn rann efter þeim þar til es Helge kastaðe hónom af bake sér; þá hvarf hann aftr. Hrómundr vas fallenn, en Þórleifr vas sárr til ólífis. Konor spurðo tíðenda. Hásteinn kvað:10

Her hafa sex þeir es sæfask....

Six Eastmen fell in the work, and the other six got away; but as Thor-beorn was about to shut the work after them, Eor-wend hurled a dart [atgar] through him. Thor-beorn took the dart out of the wound and thrust it between Eor-wend’s shoulders, so that it came out at his breast, and they both fell dead to the earth. Helge caught up Eor-wend, and cast him on his back, and so ran on. Heah-stan ran after them till Helge cast him off his back, and then he turned back. Hrod-mund had fallen, but Thor-laf was wounded to the death. The women asked what had happened. Ha-stan quoth:—

There are six wicking dead on the causeway.

Konor spurðo hve marger þeir være. Hásteinn kvað:

Varka ek fúrs með fleire, etc.

The women asked how many there were. Heah-stan quoth:—

There were four of us kinsmen against twelve sea-rovers.

Konor spurðo, hverso marger fallner være af víkingom. Hásteinn kvað:15

Siau hafa sæki tívar ... ▼

Her mego hœle-borvar ...

The women asked how many had fallen of the wickings, and Heah-stan quoth:—

Seven of them have struck the earth with their noses:

The greater half of them shall never launch their ship hence:

We gave the peace-breakers little peace....

There was a grim clatter of stone-casting, ere the sea-men turned on their heels:

The carrion bird had his prey, when Sleight Helge got a red hood:

They brought up from the ship white helmets, but they took away bloody pates.

Þeir Helge lꜵgðo út enn sama dag, ok týndosk aller á Helga-skere fyr Skriðins-enne. Þórleifr vas grœ́ddr, ok bió at Brecko, [122][167: iii. 1.]en Hásteinn fór útan ok fell á Ormenom Langa með Oláfe konunge Tryggva syne.

Helge and his mates put to sea the same day, and were all lost aboard Helge’s ship off Scridin’s-brow. Thor-laf was healed, and dwelt at [122]Brink, but Heah-stan went abroad and fell on the Long Serpent with king Anlaf Tryggwason.

5.  ▼Nú ero ritoð land-nꜵ́m flest í Vestfirðinga-fiórðunge, epter því sem fróðer menn hafa sagt. Má þat nú heyra, at þann fiórðung hefer mart stór-menne byggt, ok frá þeim ero margar5 gꜵfgar ætter komnar, sem nú mátte heyra.

5. Now are written down the most of the Settlement in the West-frith-folks’ Quarter, according to what men of knowledge have told. It may now be heard that this Quarter hath been largely settled by men of rank, from whence are come many gentle families, as might now have been heard.

[44]

Textual Notes

Saga calls Thore Thurs and Thord Beigalde.▲ 12. Eg. Saga; Holom, Cd.▲ 15. upp frá ... með] Eg. Saga; fyr sunnan Langá, H; upp með L., S.▲ 18. ofan með Langá, milli ok Hafrs-lœkjar, S; Háfs-, Eg. Saga.▲ §§ 9, 10 are taken from Egils Saga.▲ 7. út til, S.▲ 14. Son ... Sterke] add. S.▲ 16. Hit-ár] thus Cd. at leyfi Sk.-Gr.] add. S.▲ 1. ᛉ, Cd.▲ 5. Þorgeirs syner ... Torbe] add. S.▲ 9. S, S* (Grett. S.), om. Þorer.▲ 11. Þorarens, S, S*.▲ 12. ok] here is a blank in S.▲ 15. bygt hafa] land hafa numit, S.▲ 16. Here comes a single vell. leaf.▲ 1. um haustit, S.▲ 3. sœl-, vell, marmennil] S; margmelli, vell.▲ 6. bœlg-, vell.▲ 8. Ecke ... hónom] add. S.▲ 17. vóro] stóðu fyrir, S.▲ 19. Knappa-dal] ok Laxár, add. H; Þorer nam land fyr n. Kn., á mille Kaldár, ok Lax-ár, mille fiallz ok f., M*.▲ 22. Kaldarár-ós, vell.▲ 3. S; ok brann hraun, H.▲ 6. Þeirra syner ... Þórer] add. S.▲ 8. Þor­biorg, S.▲ 13. Hitar-ár] thus, vell.▲ 20. Hann, above the line.▲ 1. hann ... Goðe] add. S.▲ 4. S; ok d. Þóriðar, vell. (badly). Oddz] Oz, vell.▲ 21. Stote, S.▲ 14. ok bauð hverjom] ok laðaðe þar geste hvern es m. v. eta, S.▲ 19. með vii. mann, above the line.▲ 11. en þrælar hans ii. runno frá hónom, S.▲ 12. geck] here ends the vell. leaf.▲ 17. svá vítt, S.▲ 22. § 4 is taken from S.▲ 1. Ríka, Cd.▲ 2. laugo] thus H and S; read hauptom?▲ 6. Alofu, S.▲ 8. Vikars-, Cd.; Vikrar-, S.▲ 10. helming, S (better).▲ 12. á] í, S.▲ 16. ꜵ́to] atto, Cd.▲ sunnan] norðan, S.▲ 20. Dala-lꜵnd] here two leaves are missing in H, covering the remnant of this chapter and the whole of the 16th; thus far the text is therefore taken from S.▲ 5. þar gœrr hꜵrgr] þá gor haurg, S.▲ 6. áðr syner hans tœ́ke m.] emend.; áðr ħ tok, S (aðr . ss. ħ . tœke, Archetype); S* omits the clause.▲ 13. Spelt Haurdr and Haurdadal, S.▲ 16. átte] blank for a line left in S.▲ 17. Vifill, S here.▲ 19. œngo] S*; eigi, S.▲ 2. son Vívils] hann átte þá kono es het (blank); þeirra syner, etc., S* (Eric Red’s Saga).▲ 5. Lón-Einars] thus S; read Laugar-brecko-Einars.▲ 9. S*; Saud-kolfr, S (badly); spelt au in S.▲ 10. komet] the last line of the paragraph left blank in S.▲ 17. Skate] thus S, as it seems.▲ 1. ... ] blank for half a line in S.▲ 11. Collr ... Laxárdal] by emendation; left blank in S.▲ 16. Slettu-, S.▲ 18. Oláfr, S, here and below.▲ 20. Ceartan] Egill, adds S*.▲ 23. syner] son (s. for ss.), S.▲ 9. Odda syne] add. Egils Saga.▲ 11. Þórgerðar] add. from Laxdæla Saga.▲ 18. Mar, S.▲ 5. Emend.; Þorsnes-þ., S.▲ 13. See v. 13. 1, Asdisar, S.▲ 16. es átte ... Feilans vas] supplied from Laxdæla Saga; for here the scribe of S must have skipped a whole paragraph, containing a set of pedigrees; the bits in italics are filled in from other sources.▲ 6. Blank in S.▲ 11. Þórríðr] Þórdis, Laxd. Saga, ch. 12.▲ 6. syner vóro] son var, S (s. vͬ. for ss. vͦ).▲ 7. Orastoðum, S (badly); see Sturl. vii. ch. 330.▲ 11. leysingi Ceallacs] thus, Cirialaci libertus, Spec. (H*) maðr, S.▲ 12. Kadda kin, S.▲ 15. ok Vífill vin þ.] M*; V. var v. þeirra, S.▲ 19. þá gaf ... ey] entered in a wrong place.▲ 20. henni] emend.; birne, S.▲ eðr] áðr?▲ 1. eyna] emend.; hann, S.▲ skip] emend.; fe, S.▲ 3. sótto ... Hrafsa] emend.; stuckn þeir Eilifr ok Hrafsi, S.▲ Or kom ... Liótolfs son] add. M* (from H*, though corrupt); read, Hr(afsi) kom í gegn Eilífi pruda, ok...?▲ 5. Ceallacs syne] add. M* (H*).▲ 7. hann vas þá vii vetra] add. M* (H*).▲ 10. Hrafse geck inn ... sótto hann] according to H* (M*). Much shorter and dilapidated in S—Hrafse gekk inn á Arastauðum at boðe, hann var í kvenn fötum. Kiallakr sat á palle með skiolldFirst written felld, and since underlined.. Hrafse hió hann Asbiorn bana haugg ok gekk út um veg. Þórðr Vifelsson sagðe Hrafsa at yxin (!) hans lægi í keldu; hann bar skiold huns. Hrafse fleygðe honum fyrir kleif er hann sá Kiallaks sonu; eigi gátu þeir hann (sic) áðr þeir feldu vidu at honum. Eilífr sat hiá er þeir hann (!).▲ 5. Here H resumes the text.▲ 9. Alfs-reckom, S.▲ 13. Liufvinu, S.▲ 20. skynja] S; skoða, Cd.▲ 6. Fꜵdde þýr ... verre] emend.; fæðat þu þann kona, faer munu verri, S; fæd þu kona feordr man hann verri, H.▲ 7. þann es] þann, S; þar, Cd.▲ 9. sono sina] sveinana, S.▲ 22. Þeir G. hofðo] S; Þeir Þrondr miobeinn þeir hofðu, Cd.▲ 4. Klofsteina, S.▲ 6. Geirmunde ... Skarðe] add. S.▲ 10. Maðr hét Þróndr ... Ogðom] add. S.▲ 13. Napp-, Cd.▲ 15. Ingialldr] Ingiallz s. var s., Cd.▲ 3. vas sonr] vóro syner, S.▲ 6. ok v. et m. afar-m.] add. S.▲ 7. Guðmundr] S; Sigmundr, Cd.▲ 15. tolf] xii, Cd.; xiiii, S.▲ 5. sá] þar, add. Cd.▲ 11. Síðan átte hann ... Geirríðr ok (blank)] add. S.▲ 13. lagðr ... garðe] S; heygðr í skipe þar út frá garde, Cd.▲ 3. Ernyju, S.▲ 7. þeirra d. Halla ... Húnboga s.] add. S.▲ 10. tveimr] ij, Cd.▲ 13. Rather than Sletto-?▲ 17. at] aa, Cd.▲ 21. geriz, Cd.; gœrdiz, S.▲ 10. Osvifs, S.▲ 13. tottogo] x, S.▲ 14. eyrinne, S.▲ 20. This paragraph added from S.▲ 9. sæ-hafe] S; sæfare, Cd.▲ 10. Vínlande] Vindlande, Cd.▲ 12. þessa sogo sagðe fyrst, S.▲ 14. Gellis-son] S; Geitis-s., Cd. (badly).▲ 15. frá segja] add. S.▲ 16. néðe, S.▲ 18. í] or, S.▲ 7. Þorskafiord, S.▲ 10. lx] lxiii, Cd.▲ 14. Dufane ... -dal] Dufan var leysingi Anarr hann bió eptir í Dufans-dal, S.▲ 20. móðor] emend.; z (z = m), Cd.; om. S.▲ 1. es átte ... Eyþ. son] add. S.▲ 9. Valgerde, S.▲ 22. er átte ... iarls] om. Hárf.; hann fór til Isl. ok nam land milli þúfu, etc., S.▲ 3. dóttor Eyv. Austmannz] add. S.▲ 4. síðan] Hann átte, add. S, leaving blank for the name.▲ 8. bꜵrn] thus, S.▲ 7. en dótter Þóra ... Fiðr átte] add. S.▲ 12. dóttor Nesja-kniuks, S.▲ 14. Ottk., Cd.▲ 16. ok Úfœ́ro] til Úfæro, S. Hann vas faðer ... Liótz] S; hann var f. Þorgríms f. Þorbiarnar Skumo, f. Liótz, H.▲ 18. Chapter 24. 1–2 is taken from S; H omits it.▲ 6. Gersœme. Loékr ...] thus emend, according to Havarðar Saga; ok galt læk er fell meðal landa þeira, sá hét osóme, S; see notes. Havarðar Saga—“Þeir Liótr ok Þorbiorn [Grímr] átto eitt veite-enge báðer saman, var þat et (!) mesta gerseme ... En sa lœ́kr féll fyrir neðan bœ Liótz er fell á engit á vórit; vóro þar í stíflur ok vel um buit.’ The meadow, not the brook, took the name Jewel.▲ 13. at] af, S.▲ 15. frægra] frægan, S.▲ 8. en] er, S.▲ 16. at hꜵfðe] emend.; af h., S. kvað ... lítt] emend.; bað þá láta gott, S.▲ 3. til Stiga, ok b. þar] add. S.▲ 4. S interchanges §§ 3 and 4.▲ 8. seið] seidde, S.▲ 9. sílð] fiskom, S.▲ 13. -fialle, Cd.▲ 6. es hann ... mannenn] add. S.▲ 9. S; Onundr, Cd.▲ 11. faðer Hallgr., ok Gunnars] add. S.▲ 12. Biargeyjar] S; Biargey, Cd.▲ 16. Vebiorn, S; om. Cd. Svigna-, S.▲ 18. Efter ... fóro] add. S; þau systkin fóro, H.▲ 4 í Flióte] add. S.▲ 14 S; gengr, Cd.▲ 19 & fiorðungs-þingi á Þórsnese, S (erroneously?).▲ 3. Augrs-vík, H; Augr-vík, S.▲ 6. Snuinbroc, S.▲ 8. ecke] S; upp, Cd.▲ 13. fiórer] þrír, S.▲ 21. þrír (iii)] S; iiij, Cd., see below.▲ 2. Síðan ... aptr] add. S. Here a whole paragraph seems missing.▲ 13. Siꜵ́mk af svikom] conject.; fœs mek af sliki, Cd.; se ek af sliku, S.▲ 19. Gœ] gie, Cd.▲ 2. af hans hende Rolfs, Cd.▲ 12. hnauckotta, S.▲ 14. Þorb.] S; hann, Cd.▲ 19. Þóríðe] Þóru, S.▲ 20. systor V.] add. S.▲ 21. Þórhrolfr, S.▲ 1. Íslannz] með ráðe Harallz konungs, add. S.▲ 3. faðer] es átte, S.▲ 8. dóttor Ó., systor] S; H om. systor.▲ 11. Ásvallz son] a blank left for a name in S, but nothing is missing.▲ 7. Hvita-ský, S.▲ 14. hrænom] S; brotunom, H.▲ 16. Gerpis ok Grímolfs] add. S.▲ 6. Steinmóðr Olafsson, S.▲ 9. at] aa, Cd. es þar bió ... at sýn] add. M*.▲ 11. Trolle] add. by conj.▲ 14. Þorhrolfs ok Þór. Tosta (better?), S.▲ 20. Gisl, S.▲ 21. kom, Cd.; komz, S.▲ 6. S; Klæings, Cd. Hann var á mót Haralde konunge í Hafrs-firðe; efter þat fór hann til Ísl. ok nam, S.▲ 11. sem fyrr es ritið] (II. 4. 3) om. S, putting instead the clause, en síðan nam ... Gamla.▲ 18. Greniuðr, S. Hokins, S.▲ 19. Frá Gren ... frá Þreste] add. S.▲ 2. enn] add. S.▲ 3. Þórkels] S; Þoris, Cd. (badly).▲ 19. xv, S (better).▲ 2. aðrer sex] aðrer m̄ (vi), Cd.▲ 16. tívar ... ] two strophes, to which S adds four (all manufactured stuff).▲ 3. S adds this paragraph; om. H.

LIB. III.

Nú hefr upp Land-nꜵ́m í Norðlendinga fiórðunge ▼.

III. Here beginneth the Settlement of the North-country-men’s Quarter.

1. 1. Eysteinn Mein-fretr, son Alfs or Osto, nam Hrúta-fiarðar-strꜵnd ena Eystre næst efter Balca, ok bió þar nœkkora vetr, áðr hann fór í Dala at bua, ok feck Þórhildar,10 dóttor Þórsteins Rauðs ▼: þeirra syner vóro þeir Alfr í Dꜵlom, Þórðr, ok Þórolfr, ok Hrappr.

1. 1. Ey-stan Mein-fret, the son of Alf of Ost, took in settlement East Ram-frith-strand, next after Balci, and dwelt there certain winters before he went to settle in the Dales, and took to wife Thor-hild, the daughter of Thor-stan the Red. Their sons were these: Alf-a-Dale, Thord, and Thor-wolf, Ref [Fox] and Hrapp.

2. Þóroddr hét maðr, es nam Hrúta-fiꜵrð ▼, ok bió á Þóroddz-stꜵðom: hans son vas Arnórr Hýnefr, es átte Gerðe, dóttor Bꜵðvars or Bꜵðvars-hólom. Þeirra syner vóro þeir, Þórbiꜵrn, es15 Gretter vá, ok Þóroddr Drꜵ́po-stúfr, es orte Ofeigs-vísor ▼, faðer Valgerðar es átte Skegge, Gamla son, Þórðar sonar, Eyjolfs sonar, [123][169: iii. 1.]Eyjars sonar, Þórhrolfs sonar Fasthallda frá Snæfiꜵllom [son Skeggja Skammhondungs var Gamle, f. Alfdísar, m. Oddz Munks] ▼.

2. Thor-ord was the name of a man that took land in Ram-frith in settlement, and dwelt at Thor-ord’s-stead. His son was Arn-or Tuft-nose, who had to wife Gerd, daughter of Bead-ware of Bead-ware’s-hills. Their sons were these: Thor-beorn whom Grette slew, and Thor-ord Pæan-stump who made Un-fey’s verses, the father of Wal-gerd, whom Sceg Short-hand had to wife. He was the son of Gamle, the son of Thord, the son of Ey-wolf, the son of Ey-here, the son of Thor-wolf [123]Fast-hold of Snow-fell. The son of Sceg Short-hand was Gamle, the father of Alf-dis, the mother of Ord the monk.

2. 1. Skautaðar-skegge ▼ hét maðr ágætr í Norege. Hans son vas Biꜵrn, es kallaðr vas Skinna-Biꜵrn;5 hann vas Holmgarðz-fare. Hann fór til Íslannz, ok nam Mið­fiꜵrð, ok Línacra-dal. Hans son vas Miðfiarðar-Skegge; hann vas ▼ garpr mikill ok farmaðr ▼.

2. 1. Scautad Sceg or Beard was the name of a nobleman in Norway. His son was Beorn, who was called Skin-Beorn, for he was a traveller to Holm-garth [where he carried on his trade]. He came to Iceland, and took in settlement Mid-frith and Flax-acre-dale. His son was Mid-frith Sceg; he was a great warrior [S: and merchant].

2. Hann herjaðe í Austr-veg, ok lá í Danmꜵrk við Sióland: hann vas hlutaðr til at brióta haug Hrólfs konungs Kraka; ok tók10 hann þar or Skofnung sverð Hrólfs, ok œxe Hiallta, ok miket fé annat. En hann náðe eige Laufa; þvi at Bꜵðvarr vilde at hónom; en Hrólfr konungr varðe hann ▼.

2. He harried in the Baltic, and lay in Denmark off Sea-land. He was pitched on by lot to break into the barrow of king Hrod-wolf Crake; and out of it he took Scofnung, the sword of Hrod-wolf, and the ax of Hialte [Shelty], and much other riches; but he could not get Leaf [the sword], for Bead-were was ready to make for him, but king Hrod-wolf defended him [i.e. Sceg].

3. Hann fór til Íslannz síðan, ok bió at Reykjom í Miðfirðe, ok átte Hallbero Gríms dóttor. Syner Skeggja vóro þeir Eiðr,15 es átte Hafþóro, dóttor Þórbergs Corna-múla, ok Álofar Elliða-skialldar, systor Þórgeirs Gollnis. Þau ꜵ́tto mꜵrg bꜵrn. Annarr son Skeggja vas Collr, faðer Halldórs, fꜵðor þeirra Þórdísar, es Skálld-Helge átte, ok Þórkotlo. Dœ́ttr Skeggja vóro þær Hróðný, es átte Þórðr Geller; ok Þórbiꜵrg, es átte Ásbiꜵrn enn Auðge,20 Harðar son: dótter ▼ þeirra vas Ingibiꜵrg, es átte Illoge enn Svarte [124][170: iii. I.]á Gils-backa: þeirra syner Gunnlaugr Orms-tunga, Hermundr, ok Ketill ▼.

3. Afterwards he went to Iceland, and dwelt at Reeks in Mid-frith, and had to wife Hall-bera, Grim’s daughter. The sons of Sceg were these: Eid [Aid], who had to wife Haf-thora, the daughter of Thor-berg Cairn-mull and of A-lof Ellidi-shield, the sister of Thor-gar Gollne. These had many children. Another son of Sceg was Coll, the father of Hall-dor, the father of these,—Thor-dis, whom poet Helge had to wife, and Thor-katla. Sceg’s daughters were these: Hrod-ny, whom Thord Gelle had to wife, and Thor-borg, whom Os-beorn the Wealthy, the son of Haurd, had to wife. Their daughters were Inge-borg, whom Illuge [124]the Black, of Gil’s-beck, had to wife. Their sons were Gund-laug Worm-tongue, Hrod-mund, and Cetil.

3. 1. Haralldr Hringr hét maðr ætt-stórr. Hann kom skipe síno í Vestr-hóp, ok sat enn fyrsta vetr þar nær sem hann hafðe lent, ok nú heita Hring-staðer ▼. Hann5 nam Vatz-nes allt útan ▼ til Ambáttar-ár fyr vestan, allt inn til Þver-ár, ok þar yfir af þvero til Braga-óss, ok allt þeim-megin ▼ Biarga út til sióvar, ok bió at Hólom. Hans son vas Þórbrandr, faðer Ásbrannz, fꜵðor Solva ens Prúða ▼ á Ægis-síðo, ok Þórgeirs es bió at Hólom; hans dótter vas Ástríðr, es átte Arnmóðr Héðins10 son. Héðinn vas son þeirra. Onnor dótter Þórgeirs vas Þórgerðr, es átte Þórgrímr, son Petars frá Óse ▼.

3. 1. Harald Ring was the name of a man of great family. He came in his ship to West-hope, and sat there the first winter near to the place where he had landed, which is now called Ring-stead. He took in settlement all Water-ness from seaward as far as Bond-maid’s-river to west, all the way up [south] to Thwart-water, and over across to Brage-mouth, and on both sides of Crags north to the sea, and dwelt at Hills. His son was Thor-brand, the father of Os-brand, the father of Solwi the Proud [or Brude] of Egi-side, and also of Thor-gar [i.e. Thor-brand’s son] that dwelt at Hills. His daughter was Ast-rid, whom Arn-mod Hedin’s son had to wife. Hedin was the son of them. Another daughter of Thor-gar was Thor-gerd, whom Thor-grim, son of Peter of Oyce, had to wife.

2. Sóte hét maðr es nam Vestr-hóp, ok bió under Sóta-felle.

2. Soti was the name of a man that took in settlement West-hope, and dwelt under Soti-fell.

4. 1. hét iarl á Englande; hann átte Álofo, dóttor Ragnars Loðbrókar: þeirra bꜵrn vóro15 þau, Biꜵrn, faðer Auðunnar Skꜵkols; ok Eiríkr, faðer Sigurðar Bióða-Skalla; ok Ísgerðr, es átte Þórer iarl á Verma-lande.

4. 1. Hound Stan-here was the name of an earl in England. He had to wife A-lof, the daughter of Regin-here Lod-broc [Shaggy-breech]. Their children were these: Beorn, the father of Ead-wine Shackle, and Eiric, the father of Sig-rod Bladder-pate, and Is-gerd, whom earl Thore of Werm-land had to wife.

Auðunn Skꜵkoll fór til Íslannz, ok nam Víðe-dal, ok bió á Auðunnar-stꜵðom. Með hónom kom út Þórgils Giallande, félage hans, faðer Þórarens Goða. Auðunn Skꜵkull vas faðer Þóro20 [125][173: iii. 2.]Mos-hals, móðor Ulfilldar, es átte Goðbrandr Kúla; þeirra dótter ▼ Ásta, móðer Óláfs konungs ens Helga.... ▼ Son Auðunnar Skꜵkols vas Ásgeirr at Ásgeirs-ꜵ́; hann átte Iórunne, dóttor Ingimundar ens Gamla. Þeirra bꜵrn vóro þau, Þórvalldr, faðer Dollu, móðor Gizorar byscops: ok Auðunn, faðer Ásgeirs, fꜵðor Auðunnar,5 fꜵðor Egils, es átte Ulfeiðe, dóttor Eyjolfs Goðmundar sonar [ok var þeirra son Eyjolfr, es vegenn var á Alþinge, f. Orms capalíns Þorláks byscops ens Helga]. Annarr son Auðunnar Skꜵkols vas Eysteinn, faðer Þórsteins, fꜵðor Helga, fꜵðor Þórorms [f. Oddz, f. Hallbiarnar, f. Sigvatz prestz]. Dótter Ásgeirs at Ásgeirs-ꜵ́ vas10 Þórbiꜵrg Bœ́jar-bót ▼.

Ead-wine Shackle came to Iceland, and took Willow-dale in settlement, and dwelt at Ead-wine’s-stead. With him there came out Thor-gils Geller, his fellow, the father of Thor-arin gode. Ead-wine Shackle was the father of Thora Moss-neck, the mother of Wolf-hild, whom [125]God-brand Cula had to wife. Their daughter was Asta, the mother of king Olaf the Saint. [Two lines blank.] The son of Ead-wine Shackle was As-gar of As-gar-river. He had to wife Ior-unth or Ear-wynd, the daughter of Ingi-mund the Old. Their children were these: Thor-wald, the father of Dalla [the Blind], the mother of bishop Gizor; and Ead-wine, the father of As-gar, the father of Ead-wine, the father of Egil, who had to wife Wolf-hild, the daughter of Ey-wolf Gud-mund’s son [lat. add.], and it was their son Ey-wolf that was slain at the All-Moot, the father of Worm the chaplain of bishop Thor-lac the Saint. Another son of Ead-wine Shackle was Ey-stan, father of Thor-stan, the father of Helge, the father of Thor-worm, the father of Ord, the father of Hall-beorn, the father of priest Sigh-wat. The daughter of As-gar of As-gar’s-river was Thor-borg the Pride-of-the-Bench.

2. Ormr hét maðr, es nam Orms-dal, ok bió þar. Hann vas faðer Oddz, fꜵðor Þórvallz ▼, fꜵðor Helga, fꜵðor Harra, fꜵðor Ióro, móðor Þórdísar, móðor Tans ▼, fꜵðor Skafta.

2. Worm was the name of a man that took in settlement Worms-dale, and dwelt there. He was the father of Ord, the father of Thor-wald [S: Thor-ord], the father of Helge, the father of Harre, the father of Iora, the mother of Thor-dis, the mother of Tand [Tadg], the father of Skafte [Shafto].

5. 1. Ketill Raumr hét herser ágætr í Raums-dale í15 Norege: hann vas son Orms Skelja-mola, Hross-biarnar sonar, Raums sonar, Iotun-biarnar sonar norðan or Norege ▼. Ketill átte Miollo, dóttor Ánar Bogsveigiss. Þórsteinn hét son þeirra. Hann vá á skógenom til Upplanda, af á-eggjon fꜵðor síns, Iꜵkul, son Ingimundar iarls af Gautlande ok Vígdísar.20 [126][173: iii. 2.]Iꜵkull gaf hónom líf; síðan feck Þórsteinn ▼ Þórdísar systor hans.

5. 1. Cetil the Ream was the name of a noble herse or lord of Ream’s-dale in Norway. He was the son of Worm Shell-mull, the son of Hors-beorn, the son of Ream, the son of Iotun-beorn [Ettyn-Beorn], out of the north of Norway. Cetil had to wife Miolla, the daughter of An the Bow-swayer. Their son’s name was Thor-stan. He slew in a wood of the Uplands, at the egging of his father [Cetil], Iockle, the son [126]of earl Ingi-mund of Gaut-land and of Wigdis. Iockle gave him his life; and afterwards he took to wife Thor-dis his [Iockle’s] sister.

Þeirra son vas Ingimundr enn Gamle. Hann vas fœ́ddr í Hefni með Þóre, fꜵðor Gríms ok Hrómundar: Heiðr volva spáðe þeim ꜵllom at byggja á því lande es þá vas úfundet vestr í haf; en5 Ingimundr kvezk við því skyldo gœra. Volvan kvað hann þat eige mondo mega; ok sagðe þat til iartegna, at hlutr mœndi hverfa or pússe hans ▼, ok kvað hann þá mundo finna es hann grœ́fe fyrer ꜵndoges-súlom sínom á landeno ▼.

Their son was Ingi-mund the Old. He was brought up in the isle Hefne with Thori, the father of Grim and Hrod-mund. Heid the Sibyl prophesied to them all that they should settle in a land that was as yet undiscovered west over the sea. But Ingi-mund said that he would not do that. But the Sibyl declared that he would not be able to help it; and also told this, as a token, that the lot or teraph would disappear out of his purse, saying that he would find it when he dug a place to set up his porch-pillars in that land.

2. Ingimundr vas víkingr mikill, ok herjaðe í Vestr-víking ▼.10 Sæmundr hét félage hans Suðreyskr. Þeir kvómo or hernaðe í þann tíma es Haralldr konungr geck til lannz, ok ▼ lagðe til orrosto í Hafrs-firðe við þá Þóre Haklang. Ingimundr vilde veita konunge, en Sæmundr eige; ok skilðe þar félag þeirra. Efter orrostona gifte Haralldr konungr Ingimunde Vígdíse, dóttor Þóriss iarls15 Þegjanda. Þau Iorundr Hals vóro friðlo-bꜵrn hans. Ingimundr unðe hverge; því fýste Haraldr konungr hann, at leita forlaga sínna til Íslannz: en Ingimundr lézk þat eige ætlað hafa. En þó sende hann tvá Finna í ham-fꜵrom til Íslannz efter hlut sínom—Þat vas Freyr gœrr af silfre—Finnarner kómo aftr, ok hꜵfðo fundet20 hlutenn, ok nꜵ́ðo eige. Vísoðo þeir Ingimunde ▼ til í dale einom [127][175: iii. 3.]miðle holta þriggja ▼, ok sꜵgðo hónom allt Iannz-leg hvé háttað vas þar es þeir skyldo byggja.

2. Ingi-mund was a great wicking or warrior, and harried in the west on wicking cruises. Sæ-mund was the name of his fellow or partner, a Southrey-man. They came back from warring at the time that king Harold was coming to the land and going forth to the battle in Hafr’s-frith against Thore Long-chin and his fellows. Ingi-mund was minded to give help to the king, but not Sæ-mund; and the two partners parted there. After the battle king Harold gave in wedlock to Ingi-mund Wig-dis, the daughter of earl Thore the Silent. She and Eor-wend Halse or Neck were his children by his leman. Ingi-mund could find no peace, wherefore king Harold would have had him seek his fate in Iceland, but Ingi-mund said that he had never been minded to do so. Nevertheless he sent two Fins to go to Iceland to get back his lot or teraph, which was a Frey made of silver. The Fins came back, and they had found the teraph, but could not get it. They told that it was in [127]a dale between three [two] holts, and they told him how all the land lay, and of what kind it was which he was to settle in there.

Efter þat fór Ingimundr til Íslannz, ok með hónom Iorundr Hals, mágr hans, ok Eyvindr Sœrkver, ok Ásmundr ok Hvate viner hans ▼: ok þrælar hans, Friðmundr ok Bꜵðvarr ok Þórer5 Refskegg, ok Ulfkell. Þeir tóko Grímsár-ós fyr sunnan land ▼, ok vóro aller um vettrenn á Hvann-eyre með Gríme fóst-bróðor Ingimundar. En um váret fóro þeir norðr um heiðar. Þeir kómo í fiꜵrð þann es þeir fundo hrúta tvá—þeir kꜵlloðo þar Hrúta-fiꜵrð—síðan fóro þeir norðr um hérað, ok gꜵ́fo víða œr-nefne.10 Hann vas um vetr í Víðe-dale í Ingimundar-holte. Þaðan sꜵ́ þeir fiꜵll snælaus ▼ í land-suðr, ok fóro þangat ▼ um váret. Þar kende Ingimundr lꜵnd þau es hónom vas til vísat. Þórdís, dótter hans vas alen í Þórdísar-holte.

After this Ingi-mund got ready to go to Iceland, and Eor-wend Neck with him, his brother-in-law; and Ey-wind Sarcwe and As-mund and Hwate his friends; and his thralls, Frith-mund and Bead-were and Thore, Rof-sceg and Wolf-kell. They made Grim’s-river-mouth in the south of the land, and stayed the winter through in Hwan-eyre with Grim, Ingi-mund’s sworn brother. But in the spring they went north over the heath. They came into a frith, where they found two rams, and called it therefore Ram-frith. Then they went north over the country round, and named places far and wide. In the winter he stayed in Willow-dale at Ingi-mund’s-holt: thence they could see a snowless mountain to the south-east, and went that way in the spring. Then Ingi-mund saw and knew the land that had been pointed out to him. Thor-dis his daughter was born at Thor-dis-holt.

3. Ingimundr nam Vatz-dal allan upp frá Helga-vatne ok15 Urðar-vatne fyr austan. Hann bió at Hofe; ok fann hlut sínn es hann gróf fyr ꜵndogis-súlom sínom. Þórsteinn vas son þeirra Vígdísar; ok Iꜵkull; ok Þórer Hafrs-þió; ok Hꜵgne: Smiðr hét ambáttar son ok Ingimundar. En dœ́ttr hans Iórunn, ok Þórdís.20

3. Ingi-mund took in settlement all Water-dale up from Helge-mere and Wierd-mere in the east. He dwelt at Temple, and found his teraph there as he was digging to set up his porch-pillars. Thor-stan was the son of him and Wig-dis, and [also] Iockle and Thore Goat-thigh, and Hagene. Smith was the name of the son of Ingi-mund and a bondmaid, and his daughters were Eor-wynd and Thor-dis.

4. Iorundr Hals nam út frá Urðar-vatne, ok til Mógils-lœkjar, ok bió á Grund under Iorundar-felle. Hans son vas Márr á Márs-stꜵðom. [128] [176: iii. 3.]

4. Eor-wend Halse or Neck took in settlement land west of Horst-mere and up to Mo-gils-beck, and dwelt at Ground under Eor-wend-fell. His son was Mar [Mór] of Mar-stead. [128]

5.  ▼Hvate nam út frá Mógils-lœ́k til Gilj-ár, ok bió á Hvata-stꜵðom.

5. Hwate took land west from Mo-gils-beck to Gills, and dwelt at Hwate-stead.

6. Ásmundr nam út frá Helga-vatne of ▼ Þingeyra-sveit, ok bió under Gnúpe.

6. As-mund took in settlement land west from Helge-mere over the Thing-eyre country, and dwelt under Peak.

7. Friðmundr nam Forsœ́lo-dal.5

7. Frith-mund took in settlement For-sun-dale.

8. Eyvindr Sœrkver nam Blꜵndo-dal. Hans son vas Hermundr, ok Hrómundr enn Halte.

8. Ey-wind Sorcwe took in settlement Blond-dale. His sons were Her-mund and Hrod-mund Halt.

9. Ingimundr fann á vatne eino bero, ok tvá húna hvíta ▼ með henne;—þat kallaðe hann Húna-vatn. Efter þat fór Ingimundr útan, ok gaf Haralde konunge dýren.—Ecke hꜵfðo menn fyrr séð10 í Nórege hvíta-biꜵrno—þá gaf Haraldr konungr Ingimunde skipet Stíganda með viðar-farme, ok siglðe (hann) tveim skipom til Íslannz; ok siglðe fyr norðan land ▼ vestr um Skaga fyrstr manna, ok hélt upp í Húna-vatn—þar heiter nú Stíganda-hróf hiá Þingeyrom.15

Efter þat vas Hrafn Austmaðr með Ingimunde, ok hafðe sverð gótt; ok bar þat í hof. Því tók Ingimundr þat af hónom.

9. Ingi-mund lit upon a white she-bear, and two cubs with her, on a mere there, and called it Cub-mere. After that Ingi-mund went abroad, and gave the bears to king Harold. White bears had never been seen before in Norway. Then king Harold gave Ingi-mund the ship Stepper, with a cargo of wood aboard of her, and he sailed back to Iceland with his two ships; and sailed the north-west course round the Skaw first of all men, and held on his way to Cub-mere, to a place that is now called Stepper-dock, hard by Thing-eyre.

After this Raven the Eastman stayed with Ingi-mund, and he had a good sword, and carried it into the Temple; wherefore Ingi-mund took it from him.

10. Hallormr ok Þórormr brœ́ðr kómo út ok ▼ váro með Ingimunde. Þá feck Hallormr Þórdísar dóttor hans, ok fylgðe henne heiman Cárns-ár-land. Þeirra son vas Þórgrímr Cárnsár-goðe.20 Þórormr bió í Þórorms-tungo.

10. Hall-worm and Thor-orm, two brethren, came out and stayed with Ingi-mund. Then Hall-worm took to wife Thor-dis, Ingi-mund’s daughter, and then followed her hence as her marriage portion Cairn’s-water-land. Their son was Thor-grim, the Cairn’s-water gode. Thor-orm dwelt at Thor-orm’s-tongue.

11. Ingimunde hurfo svín tio, ok fundosk annat hausteð í Svína-dale ▼ [129][177: iii. 4.]ok vóro þá saman hundrað svína. Gꜵltr hét Beigaðr; hann hlióp á Svína-vatn, ok svamm þar til at af gengo klaufernar: hann sprack á Beigaðar-hvále.

11. Ingi-mund lost ten swine, and they were found the next harvest-tide [129]in Swine-dale, and there were then a hundred swine together. The boar was called Beigad [....]; he leapt into Swine-mere, and swam till his hooves fell off, and he died of exhaustion at Beigad’s hillock or knoll.

12. Hrolleifr enn Mikle, ok Liót móðer hans, kómo út í Borgar-firðe. Þau fóro norðr um sveiter, ok fengo œngan ráð-stafa áðr5 þau kómo í Skaga-fiꜵrð til Sæmundar. Hrolleifr vas sonr Arnallz, bróðor Sæmundar; því vísaðe hann þeim norðr á Hꜵfða-strꜵnd til Þórðar; en hann feck hónom (land) í Hrolleifs-dale, ok bió hann þar. Hrolleifr fiflðe Hróðnýjo, dóttor Una í Unaðs-dale ▼. Oddr Una son sat fyrer hónom, ok vá Liót systrung hans, en10 særðe hann á fœ́te, þvi at kyrtil hans bito eige iꜵrn. Hrolleifr vá Odd, ok tvá menn aðra; en tveir kómosk undan. Fyrer þat gœrðe Hꜵfða-Þórðr þau héraðs-sek, svá vítt sem vꜵtn féllo ▼ til Skaga-fiarðar. Þá sende Sæmundr Hrolleif tíl Ingimundar ens Gamla. Hann sette hann niðr í Oddz-ás gegnt Hofe.15

12. Hrod-laf the Big, and Leot his mother, came out and put into Borg-frith. They went north over the country side, and got no steadfast abode till they got to Sæmunds in Shaw-frith. Hrod-laf was the son of Arn-old, the brother of Sæmund, wherefore he directed them north to Thord at Head-strand, and he gave him [Hrod-laf] land in Hrod-laf’s-dale, and there he dwelt. Hrod-laf beguiled Hrod-ny, the daughter of Una [Unadh] of Unad’s-dale. Ord, Una’s son, waylaid him, and slew Leot his sister’s son; but wounded Hrod-laf himself on the foot, for iron would not bite on his kirtle. Hrod-laf slew Ord and two of his men beside, but two got away. For this Thord o’ Head made him and his mother outlaws in the hundred, as far as the rivers ran into Shaw-frith. Then Sæmund sent Hrod-laf to Ingi-mund the Old; he set him down at Ord’s-ridge, over against Temple.

Hann átte veiðe í Vatzdals-ꜵ́ við Ingimund, ok skylde ganga or ꜵ́ fyrer Hofs-mꜵnnom; en hann vilde eige or ganga fyrer ▼ sonom Ingimundar; ok bꜵrðosk þeir um ꜵ́na. Þá vas sagt Ingimunde; ok vas hann þá blindr; ok lét hann smala-svein leiða hest under ser á ꜵ́na miðle þeirra. Hrolleifr skaut spióte í gegnom hann.20 Þeir fóro þá heim. Ingimundr sende sveinenn at segja Hrolleife: [130][179: iii. 4.]en hann vas dauðr í ꜵnduge þá es syner hans kómo heim. Hrolleifr sagðe móðor sínne: hon kvað þá reyna mundo hvárt meira mætte gifta Ingimundar sona, eða kunnosta hennar; ok bað hann þá fyrst í braut fara. Þórsteinn skylde reyna efter Hrolleife, ok hafa kost-grip af arfe. Eige settosk þeir í ꜵndoge ▼ fꜵðor síns5 Ingimundar-syner. (Þeir) fóro norðr til Geirmundar ▼, ok gaf Þórsteinn hónom sex tige silfrs, at hann skyte Hrolleife braut. Ingimundar-syner rꜵkðo spor hans norðan um halsa til Vatz-dals. Þórsteinn sende húskarl í Ás á niósn. Hann kvað tolf vísor ▼ áðr til dura vas genget. Hann sá fata-hrúgo á brꜵndom, ok kom10 undan rautt klæðe. Þórsteinn kvað þar vereð hafa Hrolleif, ‘ok mun Liót hafa blóteð til lang-lífiss hónom.’ Þeir fóro í Ás, ok vilde Þórsteinn sitja yfer durom; ok náðe því eige fyrer Iꜵkle, þvi at hann vill þar vesa. Maðr geck út ok sásk ▼ um; þá leidde annarr Hrolleif efter ser. Iꜵkull brásk við, ok fellde ofan skíða-hlaða;15 en gat þó kastað kefle til brœ́ðra sínna. Hann réð á Hrolleif, ok ulto þeir báðer ofan fyr breckona, ok varð Iꜵkull efre. Þá kom Þórsteinn at, ok neytto þeir þá vápna. Þá vas Liót út komen ok geck ꜵfog; hon hafðe hꜵfoðet miðle fóta ser; en klæðen á bake ser. Iꜵkull hió hꜵfoð af Hrolleife, ok rak í and-lit Liótu.20 Þá kvazk hon of sein orðet hafa; ‘Nú mœnde um snuask iꜵrðen fyr siónom mínom, en ér mundot aller œ́rzk hafa.’ [131] [184: iii. 5.]

He had a fishery in Water-dale-river with Ingi-mund; and the Temple men had the first right of going on the river to fish. But Hrod-laf would not yield the river to the sons of Ingi-mund, and they fought across the river. This was told to Ingi-mund, who was then blind, and he bade a sheep-boy lead his horse under him to the river between them [where they were fighting]. Hrod-laf cast a spear and hit him, and then he and the boy turned home. Ingi-mund sent the boy to tell Hrod-laf; and he [130]was dead in his high seat when his sons came home. Hrod-laf told his mother; and she said it should be tried whether the luck of Ingi-mund’s sons or her knowledge [magic] should prevail; but bade him first go away. Thor-stan was set to espy after Hrod-laf, for which he was to get his choice out of the heritage. Ingi-mund’s sons would not sit in the high seat after their father. They went north to Gar-mund, and Thor-stan gave him sixty pieces of silver to thrust Hrod-laf away. Ingi-mund’s sons tracked his slot from the north over Neck to Water-dale. Thor-stan sent his house-carle to the Ridge to spy. He said that he could say twelve verses ere they answered the door. He saw a pile of clothes by the door-posts, and from under it a red coat sticking out. Thor-stan said that must have been Hrod-laf, and that Leot must have sacrificed to get him a long life. They went up to Ridge, and Thor-stan wished to waylay the door, sitting above it; but could not, because of Iockle, who wished to sit there. A man walked out and craned about; and the second man that came out led Hrod-laf after him. Iockle sprang up, and fell down off the wood-stack, but yet was able to cast the kevel to his brethren [as a sign]. He made for Hrod-laf, and they both rolled down the slope, but Iockle was uppermost. Then Thor-stan came up, and they took to their weapons. By this time Leot had got out, and she was walking backward; she had her head between her legs, and her clothes up over her back. Iockle cut off Hrod-laf’s head, and cast it in Leot’s face. Then she said that she was come too late, ‘and if I had come sooner, the earth would have turned over before the look of my eyes, and ye should all have gone mad.’ [131]

13. Efter þat kauss Þórsteinn Hofs-land; en Iꜵkull hafðe sverðet, ok bió í Tungo. Þórer hafðe goðorð, ok bió at Undorn-felle ▼, ok geck berserks-gang. Hꜵgne hafðe Stíganda, ok vas far-maðr. Smiðr bió á Smiðs-stꜵðom. Þórsteinn átte Þórríðe Gyðjo, dóttor Solmundar í Ásbiarnar-nese: þeirra son vas Ingolfr enn5 Fagre, ok Goðbrandr. Iꜵkull vas son Bárðar Iꜵkuls sonar, es Óláfr konungr enn Helge lét drepa.—Þat sagðe Iꜵkull stiga-maðr, at lenge mundo glap-víg haldask í ætt þeirre.

13. After that Thor-stan chose Temple-land; but Iockle kept the sword, and dwelt at Tongue. Thore had the gode-ship or priesthood, and dwelt at Undern-fell [Afternoon-fell], and went Bearsack’s way [became mad at times]. Hagene had Stepper, and was a merchant-shipper. Smith dwelt at Smith-stead. Thor-stan had to wife Thor-rid, the priestess, the daughter of Sol-mund of Os-beorn’s-ness. Their sons were Ing-wolf the Fair and Gud-brand. Iockle was the son of Bard, Iockle’s son, whom king Olaf the Saint had slain. Iockle, the highway-man, had said that unkindly or unlucky slaughter should long hold in their family. [Space of four lines, though nothing seems to be missing.]

14. Eyvindr Auðkúla hét maðr; hann nam Svína-dal ok bió á Auðkúlo-stꜵðom.10

14. Ey-wind Aud-cula was the name of a man that took in settlement Swine-dale, and dwelt at Aud-cula-stead.

15. Þórgils Giallande bió at Svína-vatne, es út kom með Auðunne Skokul ▼. Hans syner vóro þeir Digr-Ormr, es vꜵ́go Skarp-heðin Véfrœðar son í Vatz-skarðe.

15. Thor-gils the Yeller dwelt at Swine-mere. He had come out with Ead-wine Shackle. His sons were these: Fat-Orm and his brethren, that slew Sharp-hedin We-fred’s son at Water’s-scard or Mere-pass.

16. Eyvindr Sœrkver nam Blꜵndo-dal, sem fyrr es ritið ▼. Hans son vas Hrómundr Hallte, es vá Hꜵgna Ingimundar son, þá es15 þeir Márr ok Ingimundar syner bꜵrðosk um Deilðar-hialla: því vas hann gœrr or Norðlendinga-fiórðunge. Hans syner vóro þeir Þórbiꜵrn, ok Hásteinn, es bꜵrðosk við Sleito-Helga ▼ í Hrúta-firðe. Annarr son Eyvindar Sœrkvess vas Hermundr, faðer Hildar, es átte Ávallde Ingiallz son: þeirra bꜵrn vóro þau Colfinna, es átte20 [132][184: iii. 5.]Gríss Sæmings son; ok Brandr es vá Gallta Óttars son ꜵ́ Húna-vatz-þinge fyrer níð Hallfrœðar.

16. Ey-wind Sorcwe took in settlement Bland-dale, as it is written before. His son was Hrod-mund the Halt, who slew Hagene, Ingi-mund’s son, when Mór and the sons of Ingi-mund were fighting over Feud-shelf, wherefore he was made an outlaw in the North-country-men’s Quarter. His sons were these: Thor-beorn and Heah-stan, that fought with Sleight-Helge in Ram-frith. Another son of Ey-wind Sorcwi was Her-mund, the father of Hilda, whom A-wald Ingi-ald’s son had to wife. Their children were these: Col-finna, whom Gris Sæming’s son had to [132]wife, and Brand, who slew Galte Oht-here’s son at the Cub-mere-moot for a lampoon of Hall-fred’s.

17. Þórbiꜵrn Colcan ▼ hét maðr. Hann nam Colco-mýrar, ok bió þar meðan hann lifðe ▼.

17. Thor-beorn Colcan [Colgan] was the name of a man that took in settlement Colca-mire, and dwelt there as long as he lived.

6. 1. Ævarr ▼ hét maðr, son Ketils Hello-flaga, ok Þóríðar,5 dóttor Harallz konungs Goll-skeggs, or Sogne. Syner Ævars vóro þeir Véfrœðr ok Carle, ok Þórbiꜵrn Strúgr, ok Þórðr Mikill Ævarr fór til Íslannz or víking ok syner hans, aðrer an Véfrœðr, hann vas efter í víking. Með hónom fór út Gunnsteinn frænde hans, ok Auðolfr, ok Gautr.10

6. 1. Æw-here was the name of a man, the son of Cetil Slate-flag, and of Thor-rid, the daughter of king Harold Gold-beard of Sogn. The sons of Æw-here were We-fred and [S: his bastard sons] Carle, and Thor-beorn Stew, and Thord the Big. Æw-here went to Iceland from his wicking cruises, with all his sons save We-fred. He stayed behind on wicking cruises. With him there came out Gund-stan his kinsman, and Ead-wolf, and Geat.

Ævarr kom skipe síno í Blꜵndo-ós; þá vóro numen lꜵnd fyr vestan Blꜵndo. Ævarr fór upp með Blꜵndo at leita ser land-náms, ok kom þar sem heita Móbergs-breckor; sette hann (þar) ▼ niðr stꜵng háva, ok kvazk þar taka Véfrœðe syne sínom bú-stað. Síðan nam hann Langa-dal allan upp þaðan, ok svá þar fyr norðan hals.15 Þar skifte hann lꜵndom með skipverjom sínom. Ævarr bió í Ævars-skarðe.

Æw-here came in his ship to Blond-mouth. At that time all the land was taken and settled west of River Blond. Æw-here went up along River Blond to seek him a place to take and settle in, and reached the place which is called Mo-bergs-brink. He set up a high pole there, and declared that he took a place for a homestead there for We-fred his son. Then he took all Long-dale up thence, and so along to the mouth of the Neck. There he gave out land among his shipmates. Æw-here dwelt at Æw-here-pass.

2. Véfrœðr kom út síðarr í Gꜵngo-skarz-ár-ós, ok geck norðan til fꜵðor síns; ok kende Ævarr hann eige. Þeir glímðo svá at upp gengo stockar aller í húseno ▼ áðr Véfrœðr sagðe til sín. Hann20 gœrðe bú at Móberge sem ætlað vas: en Þórbiꜵorn Strúgr á [133][187: iii. 6.]Strúgs-stꜵðom: en Gunnsteinn á Gunnsteins-stꜵðom: Carle á Carla-stꜵðom: Þórðr (Mikill) á Mikils-stꜵðom: Auðolfr á Auðolfs-stꜵðom.

2. We-fred came out later, and landed at the mouth of Gong-scard-water or Gong-pass-river, and went thence south to his father, and Æw-here did not know him. They wrestled so that every pillar in the house was torn up before We-fred said who he was. He set up housekeeping at Mo-berg, as was settled beforehand, and Thor-beorn [133]Stew at Stew-stead, and Gund-stan at Gund-stan-stead, Carle at Carle-stead, Thord Mickle at Mickle-stead, Ead-wolf at Ead-wolf-stead.

3. Gautr bygðe í Gautz-dale; hann vas einhendr. Þeir Eyvindr Sœrkver fóro ser sialfer, ok vildo eíge lifa efter Ingimund enn5 Gamla: Haukr bió þar sem Hauks-staðer ▼ heita. Véfrœðr átte Gunnhillde, dóttor Eireks or Goðdꜵlom, systor Holmgꜵngo-Starra: þeirra syner vóro þeir Ulfheðinn, es þeir Fostolfr ok Þróttolfr vꜵ́go við Grinda-lœ́k; ok Skarpheðinn, es þeir Digr-Ormr vꜵ́go í Vatz-skarðe; ok Húnrœðr, faðor Márs, fꜵðor Hafliða.10

3. Geat settled at Geat’s-dale. He was one-handed. Ey-wind Sorcwe and he did for themselves, for they would not live after Ingi-mund the Old. Hawk dwelt at the place that is called Hawk-stead. We-fred had to wife Gund-hild, daughter of Eiric of God-dales, the sister of Battle-Wager-Starre. Their sons were these: Wolf-hedin, whom Fast-wolf and Thrott-wolf slew at Grind-beck; and Scarp-hedin, whom Orm the Fat and his fellows slew at Water-pass; and Hun-red, the father of Mór, the father of Hafledi.

4. Hollte hét maðr, es nam Langa-dal ofan frá Móberge, ok bió á Holta-stꜵðom. Hann vas faðer Ísrœðar, fꜵðor Ísleifs, fꜵðor Þórvallz, fꜵðor Þórarens (ens) Spaka. Dótter Þórvallz vas Þórdís, es átte Halldórr, son Snorra Goða; þeirra dœ́ttr vóro þær Þórkatla, es átte Goðlaugr Þórfinnz son í Straums-firðe. [Þaðan ero15 Sturlungar komner ok Odda-verjar.] Onnor (dótter) vas Goðrún, es átte Ceartan, son Ásgeirs í Vatz-firðe. Þeirra son Þórvalldr, faðer Þórðar í Vatz-firðe, ok Ingeríðr, es Goðleifr prestr átte ▼.

4. Hollte was the name of a man that took in settlement Lang-dale down from Mo-berg, and dwelt at Holte-stead. He was the father of Is-red, the father of Is-laf, the father of Thor-wald, the father of Thor-arin the Sage. Thor-wald’s daughter was Thor-dis, whom Hall-dor, the son of Snorri gode, had to wife. Their daughters were these: Thor-katla, whom Gud-laug, Thor-fin’s son of Stream-frith, had to wife, whence are the Sturlungs come and the Ord-biders; the other was Gud-run, whom Ceartan, the son of As-gar of Water-frith, had to wife. Their son was Thor-wald, the father of Thord o’ Water-frith, and Inge-rid, whom Gud-laug the priest had to wife.

5. Holmgongo-Máne hét maðr, es nam Skaga-strꜵnd fyr vestan inn til Fors-ár; en fyr austan til Mána-þúfo; ok bió í Mána-vík:20 hans dóttor átte Þórbrandr í Dꜵlom, faðer Mána, fꜵðor Kalfs skalldz.

5. Wager-Battle-Moon was the name of a man that took in settlement Shaw-strand from the west into Moon-tump, and dwelt at Moon-wick. His daughter Thor-brand-a-Dale had to wife, the father of Moon, the father of Calf the poet.

6. Eilífr Orn hét maðr, son Atla, Skíða sonar ens Gamla, [134][188: iii. 6.]Bárðar sonar í Ál: Eilífr nam land inn ▼ frá Mána-þúfo til Gongo-skarz-ár, ok Laxár-dal, ok bió þar. Hann átte Þórlaugo dóttor Sæmundar í Hlíð: þeirra syner vóro þeir Solmundr, faðer Goðmundar, fꜵðor (þeirra) Víga-Barða, ok brœ́ðra hans ▼. Annarr vas Atle enn Ramme, es átte Herdíse, dóttor Þórðar frá Hꜵfða: þeirra5 bꜵrn vóro (þau) Þórlaug, es átte Goðmundr enn Ríke; ok Þórarenn, es átte Hꜵllo, dóttor Iorundar Hals; þeirra son vas Styrbiꜵrn, es átte Yngvillde, dóttor Steinrœðar, Heðins sonar frá Heðins-hꜵfða; þeirra dótter Arndís, es átte Hamall, Þormóðs son, Þórkels sonar Mána. Son Eilífs Arnar vas Coðran at Gilj-ꜵ́, faðer10 Þórvallz Víðfꜵrla; ok Þióðolfr Goðe at Hofe á Skaga-strꜵnd; ok Eysteinn, faðer Þórvallz Tinteins, ok Þórsteins Heiðmennings, ok Arnar í Fliótom ▼.

6. Ei-lif Erne was the name of a man, the son of Atle, the son of [134]Scid the Old, the son of Bard of Al. Ei-lif took land in settlement from Moon-tump to Gong-scard-water and Lax-water-dale, and dwelt there. He had to wife Thor-laug, the daughter of Sæ-mund o’ Lithe. Their sons were these: Sol-mund, the father of Gud-mund, the father of Slaughter-Bard and his brethren. Another son was Atle the Strong, who had to wife Her-dis, the daughter of Thord o’ Head. Their children were these: Thor-laug, whom Gud-mund the Mighty had to wife, and Thor-arin, who had to wife Halla, the daughter of Eor-wend Neck. Their son was Styr-beorn, who had to wife Yngw-hild, the daughter of Stan-red, the son of Hedin of Hedin’s-head. Their daughter was Erne-dis or Arn-dis, whom Hamal, the son of Thor-mod, the son of Thor-kell, had to wife. The son of Ei-lif Erne was Codran o’ Gills-water, the father of Thor-wald the Far-farer, and Theod-wolf gode of Temple on Shaw-strand, and Ey-stan, the father of Thor-wald Tin-tan and of Thor-stan Heathman-ing, and Erne o’ Fleet.

7. 1. Sæmundr enn Suðreyske, félage Ingimundar ens Gamla, sem ritið es: hann kom skipe síno í Gꜵngo-skarz-ár-ós.15 Sæmundr nam Sæmundar-hlíð alla til Vatz-skarz fyr ofan Sæmundar-lœ́k, ok bió á Geirmundar-stꜵðom. Hans son vas Geirmundr, es þar bió síðan. Dótter Sæmundar vas Regin-leif, es átte Þóroddr Hialmr: þeirra dótter Hallbera, móðer Goðmundar ens Ríkja, fꜵðor Eyjolfs, fꜵðor Þóreyjar, móðor Sæmundar [ens20 Fróða]. Arnalldr hét annarr son Sæmundar, faðer Riúpo, es átte [135][189: iii. 6.]Þórgeirr, son Þórðar frá Hꜵfða: þeirra son vas Halldórr frá Hofe.

7. 1. Sæ-mund o’ the Southreys [Sodor Islands], the fellow or partner of Ingi-mund the Old, as hath been written before, came hither in his ship to the mouth of Gong-scard-river. Sæ-mund took in settlement all Sæ-mund-lithe as far as Water-pass down from Sæ-mund-beck, and dwelt at Gar-mund-stead. His son was Gar-mund that dwelt there afterwards. The daughter of Sæ-mund was Regin-bera, whom Thor-ord Helm had to wife. Their daughter was Hall-bera, the mother of Gudmund the Mighty, the father of Ey-wolf, the father of Thor-ey, the mother of Sæ-mund the historian. Arnold was the name of another son of Sæ-mund. He was the father of Riupa [Caper-cailzie], whom [135]Thor-gar, the son of Thord o’ Head, had to wife. Their son was Hall-dor of Temple.

2. Skefill hét maðr, es skipe síno kom í Gꜵngo-skarz-ár-ós á enne sꜵmo viko ok Sæmundr. En meðan Sæmundr fór elde um land-nám sétt, þá nam Skefill land allt fyr útan Sauð-ꜵ́; hann tók5 þat af land-náme Sæmundar at úlofe hans; ok let Sæmundr þat vesa svá buet.

2. Scefil was the name of a man that came in his ship into the mouth of Gong-scard-water in the same week as Sæ-mund. But while Sæ-mund was carrying fire about his settlement, Scefil took in settlement all the land west of Sheep-river, taking it out of Sæ-mund’s settlement without his leave; but Sæ-mund let it stand so.

3. Ulfliótr hét maðr; hann nam Langa-holt allt fyr neðan Sæmundar-lœ́k.

3. Wolf-leot was the name of a man that took in settlement Lang-holt, all down from Sæ-mund’s-beck.

4. Þórkell Vingner, Atla son, Skíða sonar ens Gamla; hann10 nam land um Vatz-skarð allt, ok Svart-ár-dal. Hans son vas Arnmóðr enn Skiálge, faðer Gallta, fꜵðor Þórgeirs, fꜵðor Styr­mess, fꜵðor Hallz, fꜵðor Colfinno.

4. Thor-kell Wingne, the son of Atle, the son of Scide the Old. He took land in settlement all over Water-dale and Swart-water-dale. His son was Arn-mod Squint, the father of Galte, the father of Thor-gar, the father of Styrme, the father of Hall, the father of Col-fina.

5. Alfgeirr hét maðr, es nam land um Alfgeirs-vꜵllo, ok upp til Mæli-fellz-ár, ok bió á Alfgeirs-vꜵllom.15

5. Elf-gar was the name of a man that took land in settlement in Elf-gar’s-field and up to Meal-fell-water, and dwelt at Elf-gar’s-field.

6. Maðr het Þórviðr, sa es land nam upp frá Mæli-fellz-ꜵ́ til Gilj-ár.

6. There was a man whose name was Thor-wide that took land in settlement up from Meal-fells-water to Gills-water.

7. Hrosskell hét maðr, es nam Svartár-dal allan, ok Ýrar-fellz-lꜵnd ꜵll með ráðe Eiriks. Hann nam ofan til Gil-haga; ok bió at Ýrar-felle. Hann átte þræl þann es Roðrekr ▼ hét; hann sende20 hann upp efter Mæli-fellz-dale í landa-leiton, suðr á Kiol. Hann kom til gils þess es verðr suðr frá Mæli-fellz-dale, ok nú heiter [136][190: iii. 7.]Rodreks-gil ▼; þar sette hann niðr staf ný-birkðan, es þeir kꜵlloðo land-kꜵnnoð. Efter þat hvarf hann aftr.

7. Horse-kell was the name of a man that took in settlement all Swart-water-dale and all Yra-fells-land with the counsel of Eiric. He took in settlement up to Gil-haye, and dwelt at Yra-fell. He had a thrall that was called Roth-ric. He sent him up along Meal-fell-dale in quest of land south on the Keel. He came to a gill that turned south out of Meal-fell-dale, which is now called Roth-ric’s-gill. There he set [136]up a fresh barked staff, which they called Land-kenner or Land-searcher, and after that he turned back again.

8. Vékell enn Hamrame hét maðr, es land nam ofan frá Gilj-ꜵ́, til Mæle-fellz-ár, ok bió at Mæle-felle. Hann spurðe ▼ ferð Hroðreks ▼, ok fór lítlo síðarr suðr á fiall í landa-leiton. Hann kom til hauga5 þeirra es nú heita Vékels-haugar; hann skaut miðle hauganna; hann hvarf þaðan aftr.

8. We-kell [Cetil] the Skin-strong [lycanthrope] was the name of a man that took land down from Gills to Meal-fell-ness, and dwelt at Meal-fell. He got news of the journey of Roth-ric; and a little later he went south on the fell in quest of land, and came to the barrows that are now called We-kell’s howes. He cast [his spear or arrow] between the barrows, and then turned back again.

En es þat spurðe Eirikr í Goðdꜵlom, sende hann þræl sínn suðr á fiall, es hét Ronguðr; fór hann enn í landa-leit. Hann kom suðr til Blondo kvísla; ok fór síðan upp með ꜵ́ þeirre es fellr fyr10 vestan Vinverja-dal, ok vestr á hraunet miðle Reykja-valla ok Kialar; ok kom þar á mannz-spor, ok skilðe at þau lꜵ́go sunnan at. Hann hlóð þar vꜵrðo þá, es nú heiter Rangaðar-varða. Þaðan fór hann aftr, ok gaf Eirikr hónom frelse fyrer ferð sína. En þaðan af tókosk upp ferðer um fiallet miðle Sunnlendinga ▼ ok Norðlendinga.15

But when Eiric of God-dale got news of this, he sent his thrall, whose name was Rongud, southward on the fell. He too went to seek out land. He came south to Blond-springs, and then went up along the river that falls from the west of Hwin-ware-dale and west on to the lava or rawn between Reek-field and Keel, and there came on a man’s slots or tracks, and guessed that they must have come from the south. He piled up a cairn there, which is now called Rongud’s cairn. From this place he went back, and Eiric gave him his freedom for his journey. But thenceforward there came about journeying over the mountains between the South-country-men and the North-country-men.

8. 1. Eirikr hét maðr ágætr. Hann fór af Norege til Íslannz. Hann vas son Hroallz ▼, Geirmundar sonar, Eiriks sonar Orðig-skeggia. Eirikr nam land frá Gilj-ꜵ́, ok Goð-dala ▼ ok ofan til Norðr-ár; ok bió at Hofe í Goðdꜵlom. Hann20 átte Þórríðe, dóttor Þórðar Skeggja, systor Helgo, es Ketilbiꜵrn [137][192: iii. 7.]enn Gamle átte at Mosfelle. Bꜵrn þeirra Eiriks vóro þau Þórkell, ok Hroalldr, Þórgeirr, ok Holmgongo-Starre, ok Gunnilldr. Þórgeirr Eiriks son átte Yngvilde, Þórgeirs dóttor: þeirra dótter Rannveig, es átte Biarne Brodd-Helga son. Gunnillde Eiriks dóttor átte Vefrœðr Ævars son ▼.5

8. 1. Eiric was the name of a nobleman. He came out of Norway to Iceland. He was the son of Hrod-wald, the son of Gar-mund, the son of Eiric Ordig-beardie. Eiric took land in settlement from Gills, over all God-dale, and down to North-water, and dwelt at Temple in God-dale. He had to wife Thor-rid, the daughter of Thord-beardie, the sister of Helge, whom Cetil-beorn the Old of Moss-fell had to wife. [137]The children of her and Eiric were these: Thor-kell and Hrod-wald, Thor-gar and Battle-wager Starre, and daughter Gund-hild. Thor-gar Eiric’s son had to wife Yngw-hild, Thor-gar’s daughter. Their daughter was Rand-weig, whom Beorn-beord Helge’s son had to wife. We-fred Æw-here’s son had to wife Gund-hild, Eiric’s daughter.

2. Krꜵ́ko-Hreiðarr hét maðr, son Úfeigs ▼ Laf-skeggs, Œxna-Þóres-sonar. Þeir feðgar bioggo skip sítt ok ▼ siglðo til Íslannz. Ok es þeir kómo í land-sýn, geck Hreiðarr til siglo; ok kvazk eige mundu kasta ꜵndogis-súlom sínom fyr borð; kvezk þat þykkja úmerkilegt at gœra ráð sítt efter því: kvezk heldr mundo heita ▼ á10 Þór, at hann vísaðe hónom til landa; ok kvazk þar mundu berjask til landa ef ▼ áðr vꜵre numet. En hann kom í Skaga-fiꜵrð, ok siglðe upp á Borgar-sand til brotz. Hávarðr Hegre kom til hans, ok bauð hónom til sin; ok þar vas hann um vettrenn í Hegranese.15

2. Crow Hred-here was the name of a man, the son of Un-fey Hang-beard, the son of Oxen-Thori. He and his father made ready their ship and sailed to Iceland; and when they came in sight of land Hred-here went to the mast, and declared that he would not throw overboard the porch-pillars, saying that he would rather make a vow to Thunder or Thor, that he would point out to him the land he was to settle in; and he declared that he would fight for it, if it were already taken in settlement by another. And he put into Shaw-frith, and sailed up to Borg-sand, and ran his ship ashore. Haward Heron came to him, and asked him to his house, and he was there through the winter at Heron-ness.

3. Um váret spurðe Hávarðr, hvat hann vilde ráða sínna; en hann kvezk ætla at berjask við Sæmund til landa. En Hávarðr latte, ok kvað þat ílla gefizk hafa; bað hann fara á fund Eiriks í Goðdꜵlom, ‘ok tak rꜵ́ð af hónom, þvi at hann es vitrastr maðr í héraðe þesso. ▼’ Hreiðarr gœrðe svá. En es hann fann Eirik,20 latte hann þessa ófriðar, ok kvað úheyrt ▼, at menn deilðe, meðan [138][193: iii. 8.]svá mann-fátt være á, landeno; kvezk helldr vilja gefa hónom Tungona alla niðr frá Skála-mýre, ok kvað Þór þangat hafa vísat hónom; ok þar hafa horft á stafn ▼ hans, es hann siglðe (upp) á Borgar-sand; kvað hónom ▼ œ́ret þat land-nám ok hans sonom. Þann kost þá ▼ Hreiðarr, ok bió á Steins-stꜵðom. Hann kauss at deyja5 í Mæli-fell. Hans son vas Ófeigr Þunn-skeggr, faðer Biarnar, fꜵðor Tungo-Steins.

3. In the spring Haward asked him what he meant to do; but he said that he had a mind to fight with Sæ-mund for land.
